channel.title: Math on up under us
channel.description: Recent content in Math on up under us

item.title: fast fourier transform
item.description: First, let’s forget the algorithm of FFT and just use it. How is it useful? It can use to multiply two polynomial. a = [1 2 3]; b = [4 5 6]; la = length(a); lb = length(b); ifft(fft(a,la+lb-1).*fft(b,la+lb-1)); ans = 4 13 28 27 18 This shows $(1x^2+2x+3)(4x^2+5x+6)=(4x^4+13x^3+28x^2+27x^1+18)$ And how to use FFT to multiply two big integers? If let $x=10$ Then can see it as $123 \times 456$ And $4 \cdot 10^4 + 13 \cdot 10^3 + 28 \cdot 10^2 + 27\cdot 10+18$ is the result we need.

item.title: mathematics
item.description: (ε, δ)-definition of limit $$(\forall\varepsilon>0)(\exists \delta > 0)(\forall x \in \mathbb{R})(0<|x-p|<\delta \implies |f(x)-L|<\varepsilon)$$ (for every real ε > 0, there exists a real δ > 0 such that for all real x, 0 < |x − p| < δ implies |f(x) − L| < ε.)
